SENT.plain: People with obesity and type 2 diabetes are at increased risk of cognitive impairment
We aimed to investigate the association of leptin with cognitive abilities in an elderly population with type 2 diabetes
We performed a cross-sectional study of 1057 men and women aged 60-75 years with type 2 diabetes living in Lothian (Scotland)
Prior intelligence was estimated from vocabulary testing and adjustment for scores on this test was used to estimate lifetime cognitive change
Relationships between fasting morning leptin levels and cognitive ability and estimated cognitive change were tested

Higher leptin levels were associated with significantly poorer estimated overall cognitive decline, and poorer performance in 2 cognitive domains assessing mental flexibility and executive function, only amongst men (p < 0.05)
High morning leptin levels in elderly men with type 2 diabetes are associated with estimated age-related cognitive change
